title: Anchoring Effect
description: People rely too heavily on the first piece of information they receive when making decisions.

title: Scarcity Bias
description: People value things more highly when they are scarce or in limited supply.

title: Framing Effect
description: People make different decisions based on how information is presented to them.

title: Halo Effect
description: People have a positive impression of something based on a single positive characteristic.

title: Social Proof Bias
description: People do or believe something because they see others doing or believing it.

title: Familiarity Bias
description: People prefer things that are familiar to them.

title: Authority Bias
description: People believe and follow the advice of someone in a position of authority.

title: Confirmation Bias
description: People seek out information that confirms their preexisting beliefs.

title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: People continue investing in something because they have already invested a lot of time or money in it.

title: Endowment Effect
description: People value something more highly simply because they own it.

title: Loss Aversion Bias
description: People avoid taking risks in order to avoid potential losses.

title: Projection Bias
description: People project their own beliefs and attitudes onto others.

title: Recency Bias
description: People give more weight to recent events or information.

title: Optimism bias
description: People overestimate their chances of success and underestimate the likelihood of negative events.

title: Groupthink
description: People go along with the majority, even if they personally disagree.

title: In-Group Favoritism
description: People favor members of their own group over those in other groups.

title: Curse of Knowledge
description: Once people know something, they asume everyone else knows it, too.

title: Automation Bias
description: People trust the output of a computer or other automated system without fully understanding how it arrived at its conclusions.

title: Google Effect
description: People rely on search engines and other online sources for information, leading to a decline in personal knowledge.

title: Belief Bias
description: People judge the validity of an argument based on their preexisting beliefs, rather than considering the evidence objectively.

title: Status Quo Bias
description: People prefer to maintain the current state of affairs, even if a change could be beneficial.
